Description: Body sherd of Corinthian black-figured pottery column-krater; interior: glazed black; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of erotic symplegma scene; part of swan, facing right (beak, neck and front of body); woman`s leg (thigh, knee and calf) in outline, to right; male legs, to left (testicle, buttock, thighs and calves; added red on buttock); two inscriptions on exterior: graffito along woman's leg and dipinto behind male's leg.
Curator's comments: Payne considers the sherd to be by the same hand as Louvre E632 and British Museum 1867,0805.860. Seeberg suggests that the sherd is loosely attached to the Klyka Group. Seeberg, A., Corinthian Komos Vases. London 1971, 65. The piece is more fully discussed by A. Johnston, 'Another two-and-a-half Corinthian dipinti', in Egraphsen kai Epoiesen (Essays on Greek pottery and iconography in honour of Professor Michalis Tiverios), Thessaloniki 2014, 119-120.
